importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2019 to 2022 saw nearly 90 glacial floods, indicating a peak of climate-related disasters in Pakistan’s mountainous regions.
The GLOF-II project launched in 2017 reflects long-term government efforts to improve early warning systems, despite persistent failures in implementation.

keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge systems—such as observing animal behavior, cloud formations, and using sound signals like gunfire—are still widely relied upon by communities in Pakistan’s mountainous regions to predict and respond to glacial floods.

Despite significant government spending (e.g., $37 million in GLOF-II project), trust in official early warning systems (EWS) is low due to frequent failures, lack of maintenance, and poor community engagement.

A lack of real-time integration between local human sensors and official rescue teams has rendered technology-based systems ineffective in many cases, with villagers relying on local heroes like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain to save lives.

Pakistan is one of the top 10 most climate-vulnerable countries despite contributing less than 1% of global emissions, with rising temperatures (1.3°C since 1950s) accelerating glacier melt and glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs).

The government has recognized the role of individual bravery—offering rewards to shepherds like Wasiyat Khan—highlighting the importance of human-based early warnings in the absence of reliable technology.

namedEntities.name: Wasiyat Khan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from Roshan Valley, Ghizer, who alerted villagers during a glacial lake outburst flood (GLOF) in the night, saving lives using indigenous knowledge.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Wasiyat Khan exemplifies how Indigenous knowledge and personal initiative are critical in disaster response when official systems fail.

namedEntities.name: Mohammad Hussain
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from Skardu Valley, Gilgit-Baltistan, who used gunfire signaling to alert villagers during a flash flood, demonstrating traditional human early warning systems.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Mohammad Hussain’s actions illustrate the effectiveness of culturally embedded, community-based alert mechanisms in the absence of working EWS technology.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A mountainous region in Ghizer, northern Pakistan, where Wasiyat Khan lives and where glacial floods are frequent.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This region is a hotspot for glacial lake outburst floods and represents a key area where Indigenous knowledge is actively used for climate adaptation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Pakistan’s mountainous Gilgit-Baltistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa regions, Indigenous knowledge—such as observing animal behavior, cloud patterns, and using sound signals like gunfire—is being used by local shepherds to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs), especially when official early warning systems fail. Despite a $37 million GLOF-II project launched in 2017, communities have shown widespread distrust due to repeated system failures, lack of maintenance, and poor community engagement. The government’s early warning systems remain ineffective, with reports indicating no real-time link between local sensors and rescue teams. In contrast, individuals like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain have saved lives through traditional, community-based alerting methods. Climate change is exacerbating the situation, with rising temperatures accelerating glacier melt and increasing flood risks. The article highlights the urgent need for integrating Indigenous knowledge with official systems to build climate resilience, especially in one of the world’s most climate-vulnerable nations.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
